title: Do you need to have a book copyright to publish the translation of the book? - Quora

response.answer_text: The exact thing you need is to license the copyright to publish the version for the language you intend. The question is, who has the copyright for this? Foreign-language rights start with the copyright owner (typically, the author), but these are often included in the book contract with the publisher. At that point, the publisher has the copyrights for foreign-language versions. These copyrights can then be licensed to people, like yourself, to translate and publish in other languages. Since there’s no public record you can look up about this, your best path is to contact the current publisher of the book. Ask if they have the right to publish in the language you intend. If they do, ask about their process for licensing that right. If the publisher did not license this right from the author, then ask if the publisher will connect you with the author to pursue it with her/him. Be aware, however, that if you have no experience in publishing this can all get very tricky. You need to understand what you’re getting into legally, as this would be a proper contract. On top of that, you need to understand the business of publishing so that you can pursue this smartly and ultimately to reach your goals. If you have neither of these — let’s say you just have a strong interest in translating this book into a new language — then I’d first propose your idea to the existing publisher. Convey (1) your interest in this project, (2) your qualifications to translate the book, and (3) why you think this book would be successful in the translated language. To this last point, show any market research you can to demonstrate the realistic sales potential and why. It’s also possible the publisher already has a foreign-rights partner it works with, which may preclude a contract with you (or would need to involve that partner). If the publisher is interested in your proposal, you could end up with a simple “work for hire” agreement in which you would be paid a guaranteed fee to translate the book. This is far simpler and less risky than attempting to be the publisher of this book in the new language. However, being the publisher offers greater potential if there’s a strong market for the book. You’ll have to decide which path is best based on your interest, skills, and resources. But first things first… determine who holds the copyright for the language you want to publish in. And then go from there. Thanks for the A2A! [Answered: Do you need to have a book copyright to publish the translation of the book?]

If it’s somebody else’s book, be sure you’re covered by permissions and other legal protections. Otherwise, you’re going to be sued big-time. All platforms where the translation appeared would get the appropriate letter. Something which would possibly get you banned from dealing with them in the future. If it’s your book, a translation would merit a new ISBN. An new ASIN would be needed if it’s an eBook (Amazon). Other platforms have their own internal book identification systems.
You need to have the permission of the author and the author’s original publisher. This will cost you money.

You need the permission of the copyright holder. Generally speaking, publishers usually negotiate the terms for a translator of a work; sometimes they merely hire someone to do the translation. Or a publisher in a different country may seek permission to publish a translation, and hire a translator. I am not sure how often a translator seeks permission (and receives it) to do a translation, but I don’t think it happens real often.
if the copyright in the book has not expired, then you need permission from the copyright owner to make a translation of the book.

A translation requires a separate copyright from the original language version, but you better have permission from the author (unless the original book is in the public domain) before you publish a translation, because translation rights belong to the author, too.
If you are translating a book that you have the copyright on, probably not. If it's someone else's book, you must have permission of the copyright holder to do so.
You need permission from the original author to create a derivative work. Once you have that and you write your translation, you’ll also have your own copyright on the translation.
If you want to translate a book that is copyrighted you can do so only with the permission of the copyright holder of the original book.
